we believe, inextricably bound up with the

that "response to needs" is the most critical factor

From time to time there have been outraged cries
from certain sectors of our society when we re¬
commended the expenditure of "almost" as much
money, for the education and rehabilitation of the
poor and disadvantaged youth, as an average American
middle-class family spends for the education of
their children. Yet, we know that the law says
that no child shall be deprived of the right to
an adequate education, or a person of the right
to work, if he is capable. In spite of that, we
know that the central issue for the poor, and
more intensely for the minority poor, remains sbcial
reinforcement of deprivation by exclusion. And
this intolerable condition does exist, in our
country, in the latter half of the Twentieth Century.
